definition: old-fashioned women's obeisance/Taiwan pr. [lian4 ren4]
variant of 殮|殓[lian4]
to hold back/to restrain/to control (oneself)/to collect/Taiwan pr. [lian4]
(literary) overlapping part of Chinese gown/lapel/sleeping mat
variant of 衽[ren4]
variant of 斂衽|敛衽[lian3 ren4]
to salute/to greet
to bow deeply, starting upright with arms straight out in front, one hand cupped in the other, then moving the hands down to one's knees as one bows, keeping the arms straight (a form of greeting)
to bow down low/to make obeisance/to kneel and bow
to bow
to greet by raising clasped hands
to salute/to make one's salutations
to return a politeness/to present a gift in return
to half rise out of one's chair (a polite gesture)
to cup one fist in the other hand (as a sign of respect)
to walk slowly/with deliberate steps
to bow with hands held in front
to petition for retirement (old)/to ask for leave to withdraw/to ask to be excused
to kowtow in salute
(formal) you may dispense with curtseying
to cup one's hands in obeisance or greeting/(fig.) submissive
